ygData.subject: Re: initial concentrations at z=0 for flame1.py, bug or not
ygData.msgSnippet: Mea culpa! It is no bug, but a very nice piece of software! I recognized the underestimated effect of back-diffusion in the calculations playing a little bit

Mea culpa!
It is no bug, but a very nice piece of software!
I recognized th=
e underestimated effect of back-diffusion in the
calculations playing a lit=
tle bit around with the mass flux and
pressure during the weekend (the orig=
inal post was from saturday
morning). 
Thanks to D. Huckaby and D. Goodwin =
for their answers.

Holger
--- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, "hdoe71" <holger=
.doerr@...> wrote:
>
> Hello,
> running the flame1.py burner stabilized fla=
me simulation I recognized
> that the concentration of H2O (water) is at z=
=3D0 about a third of the
> final concentration, a  little depending on the=
 pressure. From my
> knowledge of mass balancing the initial concentration =
must be 0 for
> water, and the concentrations at z=3D0 unequal to zero shou=
ld be only
> those of the educts hydrogen, oxygen and the inertial gas argo=
n. 
> I've used the unaltered script flame1.py of cantera-1.6.0, varied onl=
y
> the pressure within 0.03-1 atm. A similar behaviour is observable for
>=
 CK II running premixed H2-O2-Ar flames or C2H2-O2-flames, but this is
> no=
 CK II group, but interesting for me (some form of oo-inheritance?-). 
> Te=
xtbooks about combustion (Warnatz et al.) show graphs with initial
> water =
concentrations of zero. 
> Is something wrong in my interpretation of the r=
esults in flame1.csv? 
> 
> Best regards from Germany
